data.text: @ItaOKelly How many languages do you speak fluently Ita? Worked in Google Dublin for three years myself, the only Irish there who were fluent in French Spanish etc. were Gaeilgeoirí. Speak two languages fluently and you'll pick up others. Your article misses this fact completely.
@ItaOKelly PS the extra points for doing exams in Irish has no relation to Irish being compulsory. Also bare in mind that the government won't provide Irish language text books for all subjects
@ItaOKelly The idea that we have to stop speaking Irish to become a "modern" European country doesn't make any sense
@noisyoptimist @ItaOKelly  https://t.co/c0TyvAV3B9
@Casserly_Rock @ItaOKelly 😮 Not sure how my OH would feel about that, but I’m sure he’ll consider your offer if necessary!
@ItaOKelly Finns, Danes, Dutch etc can speak 3-4 languages. Their native languages are no barrier to being multilingual. Finnish is not spoken outside of Finland either
@noisyoptimist @ItaOKelly If that doesn't work, I'm open to a marriage of convenience https://t.co/C6WynyefHf
@noisyoptimist @ItaOKelly Might be a generation too far back but no harm in trying :-)

@Casserly_Rock @ItaOKelly I never knew that. Apparently my ancient ancestors came from the Galician/Asturias area before settling in central Spain in the 15th Century. Perhaps others went to Ireland! Is that enough of a link to get an Irish passport????
@ItaOKelly Surely it's the English language that's to blame for our monolingualism - they don't teach Irish in the UK but their figures are barely better than ours.
@noisyoptimist @ItaOKelly There may be, given that early Irish settlers came from the Iberian peninsula. Galicia in particular shares similarities in the language.
@ItaOKelly It's our native language

@ItaOKelly 2/2 Your article does not even mention Spanish, which I assume was just an oversight. However I agree about teaching from an early age. I teach Spanish to 7 year olds and their enthusiasm is infectious.

@ItaOKelly Although Mandarin is most widely spoken in number of people. Most speakers are located in a particular geographical location. English is the most widely spoken language in terms of locations followed by Spanish. 1/2
@Casserly_Rock @ItaOKelly Whenever I met someone Irish speaking Spanish I was always amazed at their excellent pronunciation, as if there is a natural affinity with the two accents.
@Casserly_Rock Yes, well put!
@ItaOKelly The Dunning-Kruger effect.
@Casserly_Rock This is it. People are not always honest or even accurate when answering questions.
@ItaOKelly Then I realised, a lot of people know less French than that and will claim to speak the language.
@ItaOKelly I was going to say nobody would claim to speak French just because they can say Merci and ask directions to the station.
@ItaOKelly Yep, they can trot out a few stock phrases, but that's it. Mind you, two years of suffering the writing of Peig Sayers, forgetting Irish is a defense mechanism.
@Casserly_Rock I think many people have a blind spot about Irish. They claim they can speak the language but have no fluency.
@ItaOKelly I would wager that more Chinese, Korean and Japanese people speak fluent Irish than those of us who went through the Irish education system.
